They look more like the latest chapters in our national struggle to make equal justice and equal protection of the law into facts of life for all Americans rather than contingencies that sometimes depend on the color of one’s skin. Obviously this struggle remains incomplete.
These disturbing events do not look like three isolated incidents.

Americans from coast to coast have been grieved and horrified by the killings of African-American citizens: Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia Breonna Taylor in my hometown of Louisville Kentucky and George Floyd in Minneapolis.  https://t.co/Z3fe4NFwfo
There is no constitutional right to commit violent crime or to terrorize communities. Period. This cannot continue. https://t.co/gMl9puEvae
You do not advance peace by committing assault. You do not advance justice by inflicting injustice upon your neighbors. You do not promote the rule of law through anarchy.
It does not advance freedom or justice to vandalize the World War II Memorial that stands for those who bled and died for exactly those values.

It is not a display of courageous citizenship to smash and destroy small businesses that had just barely hung on through this pandemic. It is not an act of principled protest to grab expensive merchandise or set fire to a church.
Free speech and peaceful protest are central American liberties. Looting rioting assault and arson are violent crimes that have no place whatsoever in our society.

We have seen small businesses destroyed and public property defaced. We have seen the men and women of law enforcement — the vast majority of whom are not bad actors but brave public servants — threatened and assaulted on our own streets.
Americans have watched protests dedicated to ending unjust violence mutate into riots that inflict unjust violence themselves.

Citizens have watched with horror as cities across America have convulsed with looting riots and destruction. On a nightly basis initially peaceful demonstrators have been hijacked. https://t.co/gMl9puEvae

I’m proud Congress ultimately rejected political posturing and voted to send immediate relief to American families small businesses and healthcare workers.
For Kentuckians on Medicare it also expands access to telehealth services which can be particularly important in rural areas.
Finally the CARES Act bolsters the healthcare response to the coronavirus. It addresses supply and testing shortages fuels innovation and funds hospitals and healthcare providers.

To fight the virus’ spread our government practically shut down entire sectors of the economy. Additional programs will also deliver targeted federal resources to employers in an effort to prevent as many layoffs as possible.
We are hopeful this rapid injection of cash can help Main Street businesses continue paying workers and survive the crisis.  Our third objective looks to shore up our country’s economic foundations.

Small employers in Kentucky account for more than 99% of our businesses employing nearly 700000 workers. Our second priority helps keep their lights on through hundreds of billions in federally guaranteed loans.

First our bill puts cash directly into the hands of the American people. Eligible Kentuckians will get up to $1200 for individuals along with student loan deferments and other benefits. For middle-class workers seniors and those laid off we’re sending critical relief.
And in about a week I shepherded the bipartisan bill to Senate passage with a 96-0 vote and on to President Trump’s desk to become law.

I introduced legislation reflecting the task forces’ best ideas called the Coronavirus Aid Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act. It became the foundation for our country’s largest economic relief legislation.
